explanation:
MHD_get_master — The function assigns the parameter daemon = MHD_get_master(daemon). To decide if the target function violates the MISRA rule (a function parameter shall not be modified) we must see the prototype/definition of MHD_get_master to confirm there is no macro/inline trickery and to understand the intended semantics of that assignment. The mere assignment of the parameter variable inside the function is the spot most likely to be a MISRA violation, so inspecting MHD_get_master is essential.

MHD_ip_addr_to_key — Called with the parameter addr (const struct sockaddr_storage *). To ensure the parameter addr (and its pointed-to object) are treated correctly per MISRA rules we need the prototype/definition of MHD_ip_addr_to_key to verify const-correctness and to ensure it does not rely on or cause any covert modification of the addr parameter or perform casts that would mutate the caller’s object in violation of qualifiers.

MHD_ip_count_lock and MHD_ip_count_unlock — Both are called with daemon and might be macros or inline functions. To fully check whether the target function itself modifies any of its formal parameters (or whether those symbols expand to code that does so), the definitions/prototypes are required. If they are simple functions, they won't change the fact that the formal parameter daemon was reassigned earlier, but if they are macros they could hide additional assignments or side-effects involving the parameter identifier.

MHD_DLOG — Used with daemon in an #ifdef path. Its definition (macro or function) should be examined to ensure it does not expand to code that modifies any of the formal parameters (especially daemon) or otherwise introduces side-effects relevant to the MISRA parameter-modification rule.
